name: Lee Ho-Wang
summary: Already may exist - checking. Lee Ho-Wang discovered Hantaan virus.

name: Hwang Cheol-seong
summary: Hwang Cheol-seong is a Korean chemist at Seoul National University who has made significant contributions to atomic layer deposition (ALD) technology for semiconductor manufacturing. His research on high-k dielectric thin films has been adopted by global semiconductor manufacturers for advanced chip production.
timeline: ALD technology widely adopted in semiconductor industry

name: Cho Jang-hee
summary: Cho Jang-hee is a Korean electrical engineer who contributed to the development of radio-frequency identification (RFID) and Internet of Things (IoT) technology in South Korea. His research on sensor networks and wireless communication systems has advanced Korean capabilities in smart logistics and connected devices.

name: Baik Hae-gu
summary: Baik Hae-gu is a Korean civil engineer who has designed many of South Korea's landmark bridges, including cable-stayed and suspension bridges. His engineering innovations in bridge design have been exported to other countries, establishing Korea as a global leader in bridge construction technology.

name: Park Jeong-ho
summary: Park Jeong-ho is a Korean battery scientist who has contributed to the development of next-generation battery technologies at LG Energy Solution. His research on solid-state batteries and silicon anode materials aims to create safer, longer-lasting batteries for electric vehicles.

name: Chung Mong-joon
summary: Chung Mong-joon is a Korean engineer and politician who served as chairman of Hyundai Heavy Industries and contributed to Korea's shipbuilding and offshore engineering technology development. He oversaw the construction of some of the world's largest ships and offshore platforms.
timeline: Earned PhD from Johns Hopkins University

name: Yoo Ryong-jun
summary: Yoo Ryong-jun is a Korean nuclear fusion scientist who has contributed to the development of the KSTAR (Korea Superconducting Tokamak Advanced Research) fusion reactor. KSTAR has set multiple world records for sustaining high-temperature plasma, advancing the global quest for fusion energy.
timeline: KSTAR sustained 100 million degree plasma for 30 seconds
KSTAR set new plasma duration record

name: Kim Sang-hyung
summary: Kim Sang-hyung is a Korean marine biotechnologist who has researched bioactive compounds from Korean marine organisms. His work on marine-derived enzymes and pharmaceuticals has contributed to Korea's blue biotechnology sector, discovering novel compounds with antimicrobial and anticancer properties.

name: Park Sung-hyun
summary: Park Sung-hyun is a Korean AI researcher who has contributed to natural language processing and machine learning research at major Korean tech companies. His work on Korean language AI models has advanced Korean-language AI capabilities and contributed to the development of conversational AI systems.

name: Ogata Tomio
summary: Ogata Tomio was a Japanese polymer chemist who developed novel polymerization methods at Tokyo Institute of Technology. His research on ring-opening polymerization and condensation polymerization contributed to the development of engineering plastics used in automotive and electronics industries.

name: Morino Yoshihide
summary: Morino Yoshihide was a Japanese physical chemist who pioneered gas-phase electron diffraction studies of molecular structures in Japan. His precise measurements of molecular geometries advanced understanding of chemical bonding. He established physical chemistry research at several Japanese universities.

name: Mizushima San-ichiro
summary: Mizushima San-ichiro was a Japanese physical chemist who pioneered the study of molecular conformations using infrared spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy. He demonstrated that organic molecules can exist in different rotational conformations, establishing conformational analysis in chemistry. His work predated similar Western discoveries.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Tokyo

name: Nozoe Tetsuo
summary: Nozoe Tetsuo was a Japanese organic chemist who discovered tropolone and troponoid chemistry, an entirely new class of non-benzenoid aromatic compounds. His work on seven-membered aromatic ring systems expanded the theoretical understanding of aromaticity beyond benzene-based compounds and opened new areas of organic chemistry.

name: Nishikawa Shoji
summary: Nishikawa Shoji was a Japanese physicist who pioneered X-ray crystallography in Japan and independently observed X-ray diffraction from fibrous materials, contributing to structural biology. He made early observations of crystal structures using X-ray diffraction, advancing Japanese materials science.
timeline: Studied physics at University of Tokyo
Published X-ray studies of fibrous materials

name: Rikitake Tsuneji
summary: Rikitake Tsuneji was a Japanese geophysicist who developed the Rikitake dynamo model for geomagnetic field reversals. He also worked extensively on earthquake prediction research and developed theories about precursory electromagnetic phenomena before earthquakes. He served as president of the International Association of Geomagnetism.

name: Torahiko Terada
summary: Torahiko Terada was a Japanese physicist, geophysicist, and essayist who studied a wide range of natural phenomena including X-ray crystallography, crack patterns, smoke rings, and volcanic lightning. He pioneered the scientific study of everyday natural phenomena and was known as a 'physicist-poet' for his literary scientific essays. He established experimental physics at the University of Tokyo.
timeline: Studied under William Bragg in London
Published scientific essays combining art and physics

name: Ito Hirobumi
summary: While Ito Hirobumi was primarily a statesman (first Prime Minister of Japan), he played a crucial role in Japan's scientific modernization by establishing institutions that promoted Western science and technology adoption during the Meiji era. He founded the modern Japanese university system and promoted industrialization through technology transfer.
timeline: Traveled to London, saw Western technology
Led Iwakura Mission to study Western nations
Became first Prime Minister of Japan

name: Kiyoura Keigo
summary: Kiyoura Keigo served as Prime Minister of Japan and oversaw policies promoting scientific education and industrial modernization. His governance during the early 20th century supported the expansion of Japanese scientific institutions and the adoption of modern engineering practices in infrastructure development.

name: Kanehiro Takaki
summary: Kanehiro Takaki was a Japanese naval surgeon who eradicated beriberi from the Japanese Navy through dietary reform in 1884, decades before the vitamin B1 deficiency cause was understood. He demonstrated that providing a varied diet (rather than polished rice alone) prevented beriberi, saving thousands of sailors' lives. He is considered the father of clinical nutrition in Japan.
timeline: Studied at St Thomas' Hospital, London
Became head of Tokyo Naval Hospital
Eliminated beriberi in Navy through dietary reform
Founded Jikei University School of Medicine

name: Tsukuba Michitaka
summary: Tsukuba Michitaka was a Japanese computer engineer who contributed to the development of Japan's supercomputer industry. His work on high-performance computing systems at NEC helped Japan achieve world-leading computational capabilities in the 1980s and 1990s with the SX series supercomputers.

name: Maki Fumihiko
summary: Fumihiko Maki is a Japanese architect who won the 1993 Pritzker Prize for his synthesis of Eastern and Western architectural philosophies. His engineering innovations in metallic surfaces and lightweight structures advanced architectural technology. He designed the 4 World Trade Center in New York and the Tokyo Metropolitan Gymnasium.
timeline: Graduated from Cranbrook Academy of Art
Completed 4 World Trade Center, New York

name: Ando Tadao
summary: Tadao Ando is a self-taught Japanese architect who won the 1995 Pritzker Prize. Without formal architectural education, he developed an innovative style using exposed concrete and natural light. His engineering of light through precise openings and water features demonstrates exceptional understanding of physics and materials. The Church of the Light is his masterpiece.
timeline: Built Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth

name: Xu Xing
summary: Xu Xing is a Chinese paleontologist who has named and described more dinosaur species than any other living scientist — over 70 species. His discoveries of feathered dinosaurs in China provided crucial evidence for the dinosaur-bird evolutionary link. He has transformed our understanding of theropod evolution and the origin of flight.
timeline: Earned PhD from Chinese Academy of Sciences

name: Jiao Nianzu
summary: Jiao Nianzu was a Chinese physicist and historian of science who documented the history of physics in China and the contributions of Chinese physicists. His scholarly works preserved the record of Chinese scientific achievements and the challenges faced by Chinese scientists during periods of political turmoil.

name: Huang Kun
summary: Huang Kun was a Chinese physicist who co-authored 'Dynamical Theory of Crystal Lattices' with Max Born in 1954, one of the most important texts in solid-state physics. The Huang-Born theory describes lattice vibrations and their interactions with electromagnetic radiation. He later became president of Peking University and received China's State Preeminent Science Award.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Bristol
Returned to China, joined Peking University
Co-authored crystal lattice dynamics with Born
Received State Preeminent Science and Technology Award

name: Xie Xide
summary: Xie Xide was a Chinese physicist who became the first female president of Fudan University and a pioneer of semiconductor physics in China. She helped establish surface physics research in China and trained a generation of Chinese physicists. Despite physical disabilities from childhood tuberculosis, she made major contributions to Chinese science.
timeline: Established semiconductor physics program at Fudan
Became first female president of Fudan University

name: Zhao Zhongyao
summary: Zhao Zhongyao was a Chinese nuclear physicist who was the first to observe the anomalous absorption of hard gamma rays by lead in 1930 at Caltech, which was later recognized as evidence of positron-electron pair production. Though he did not receive credit at the time, his observation predated Anderson's positron discovery. He helped found Chinese nuclear physics.
timeline: Observed anomalous gamma ray absorption at Caltech
Anderson discovered positron (related to Zhao's observations)

name: Zhou Peiyuan
summary: Zhou Peiyuan was a Chinese theoretical physicist who made contributions to general relativity, fluid mechanics, and turbulence theory. He studied under Einstein's collaborator at Caltech and returned to China where he served as president of Peking University. He was one of the founders of modern physics education in China.
timeline: Studied under Einstein and worked on general relativity

name: Wang Ganchang
summary: Wang Ganchang was a Chinese nuclear physicist who independently proposed the use of cloud chambers to detect neutrinos in 1941 and discovered the anti-sigma-minus hyperon at CERN in 1959. He was a key figure in China's nuclear weapons program and helped develop China's first atomic and hydrogen bombs.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Berlin
Joined Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna
Returned to China for nuclear weapons research
Contributed to China's first atomic bomb

name: He Zehui
summary: He Zehui was a Chinese nuclear physicist and wife of Qian Sanqiang who co-discovered nuclear ternary and quaternary fission while working at the Joliot-Curie laboratory in Paris. She was one of China's most important female physicists and contributed to the development of China's nuclear program. She was a pioneer of nuclear emulsion techniques.
timeline: Earned PhD from Technical University of Berlin
Co-discovered nuclear ternary fission in Paris

name: Qiu Chengtong
summary: Qiu Chengtong (Shing-Tung Yau) is a Chinese-American mathematician who won the Fields Medal in 1982 for proving the Calabi conjecture, which became fundamental to string theory and theoretical physics. Calabi-Yau manifolds, named after him and Eugenio Calabi, describe the extra dimensions in string theory. He has made profound contributions to geometry and mathematical physics.
timeline: Graduated from Chinese University of Hong Kong
Earned PhD from UC Berkeley at age 22

name: Zhang Shouzheng
summary: Zhang Shouzheng (Shoucheng Zhang) was a Chinese-American physicist who made groundbreaking contributions to topological insulators and predicted the quantum spin Hall effect. His work at Stanford on topological states of matter was widely expected to earn a Nobel Prize. He also proposed the existence of the angel particle (chiral Majorana fermion). He died in 2018.
timeline: Earned PhD from Stony Brook University
Quantum spin Hall effect confirmed experimentally

name: Xue Qikun
summary: Xue Qikun is a Chinese physicist at Tsinghua University who led the first experimental observation of the quantum anomalous Hall effect in 2013, achieving dissipationless electron flow without an external magnetic field. This breakthrough, predicted by his colleague Zhang Shouzheng, was one of the most important physics discoveries of the decade.
timeline: Earned PhD from Chinese Academy of Sciences
Observed quantum anomalous Hall effect experimentally
Received State Natural Science Award First Prize

name: Nan Rendong
summary: Nan Rendong was a Chinese astronomer and engineer who conceived, designed, and oversaw the construction of FAST (Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope), the world's largest single-dish radio telescope. Located in Guizhou Province, FAST surpassed the Arecibo Observatory in sensitivity. Nan dedicated over 20 years to the project before dying shortly after its completion.

name: Zheng Xiaoying
summary: While Zheng Xiaoying was primarily a renowned conductor, she was notable as China's first female symphony orchestra conductor. Her systematic approach to musical interpretation and her role in founding music education institutions contributed to cultural and intellectual development in China. She demonstrated that women could lead in traditionally male-dominated technical fields.
timeline: Became China's first female orchestra conductor
Conducted at Central Conservatory of Music

name: Tan Dun
summary: Though primarily a musician, Tan Dun is notable for his innovative use of natural materials and technology in music. He creates instruments from water, paper, and organic materials, merging art with acoustic science. His Water Concerto and Paper Concerto explore the physics of sound in novel ways. He won the Academy Award for Crouching Tiger music.
timeline: Moved to New York to study at Columbia
Won Academy Award for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon

name: Takeuchi Yoshinori
summary: Takeuchi Yoshinori was a Japanese volcanologist who studied the volcanic activity of Japan's numerous active volcanoes. His research on eruption prediction, lava flow modeling, and volcanic gas monitoring contributed to Japan's volcano early warning systems, helping protect millions of people living near active volcanoes.

name: Wadati Kiyoo
summary: Wadati Kiyoo was a Japanese seismologist who discovered deep-focus earthquakes and the relationship between earthquake depth and distribution (the Wadati-Benioff zone). His observations of earthquakes at depths greater than 300 km challenged existing theories and contributed to the development of plate tectonics theory.
timeline: Became director of Japan Meteorological Agency

name: Matuyama Motonori
summary: Matuyama Motonori was a Japanese geophysicist who provided the first evidence that Earth's magnetic field has reversed polarity in the past. By studying the magnetization of basalt rocks in Japan and Manchuria in the 1920s, he showed that some rocks were magnetized in the opposite direction to the current field. The Matuyama reversed polarity epoch is named after him.
timeline: Confirmed magnetic field reversals in basalt

name: Fujita Tetsuya Theodore
summary: Tetsuya Theodore Fujita was a Japanese-American meteorologist who created the Fujita Scale (F-Scale) for rating tornado intensity in 1971. Known as 'Mr. Tornado,' he also discovered microbursts, dangerous wind shear events that had caused multiple aircraft crashes. His microburst discovery led to improved aviation safety, saving thousands of lives.
timeline: Studied Hiroshima and Nagasaki bomb damage patterns
Created Fujita Scale for tornado intensity
Microburst research led to improved aviation safety

name: Wasaburo Ooishi
summary: Wasaburo Ooishi was a Japanese meteorologist who discovered the jet stream in the 1920s by tracking weather balloons over Japan. He published his findings in Esperanto, which limited their international impact. His discovery of these high-altitude, high-speed wind currents was decades ahead of Western recognition of the jet stream.
timeline: Published discovery of jet stream in Esperanto
Jet stream knowledge used by Japanese balloon bombs

name: Sakurai Jun John
summary: Jun John Sakurai was a Japanese-American theoretical physicist who made important contributions to particle physics and wrote one of the most widely used graduate textbooks in quantum mechanics, 'Modern Quantum Mechanics.' His textbook, completed posthumously by San Fu Tuan, remains the standard reference for teaching quantum mechanics at the graduate level.
timeline: Died in Geneva while visiting CERN

name: Tomonaga Sin-Itiro
summary: Already covered - see Tomonaga Shin'ichiro. Duplicate check.

name: Nambu Yoichiro
summary: Nambu Yoichiro was a Japanese-American physicist who won the 2008 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering the mechanism of spontaneous broken symmetry in particle physics. His work explained how particles acquire mass and was foundational for the Standard Model. The Nambu-Goldstone theorem and Nambu-Jona-Lasinio model are named after him.
timeline: Proposed spontaneous symmetry breaking in particle physics
Proposed color charge in quantum chromodynamics

name: Kobayashi Makoto
summary: Already covered - see Makoto Kobayashi. Duplicate check.

name: Ting Samuel Chao Chung
summary: Samuel C.C. Ting is a Chinese-American physicist who shared the 1976 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering the J/psi particle (J particle), which provided evidence for the charm quark. His discovery at Brookhaven National Laboratory confirmed the existence of a new quark flavor, extending the Standard Model. He leads the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer experiment on the ISS.
timeline: Born in Ann Arbor, Michigan (Chinese parents)
Earned PhD from University of Michigan
AMS-02 installed on International Space Station

name: Daniel Tsui
summary: Daniel Tsui is a Chinese-American physicist who shared the 1998 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering the fractional quantum Hall effect, which revealed a new form of quantum fluid with fractionally charged quasiparticles. His 1982 experiment with Horst Störmer at Bell Labs uncovered one of the most remarkable quantum phenomena in condensed matter physics.
timeline: Earned PhD from University of Chicago

name: Steven Chu
summary: Steven Chu is a Chinese-American physicist who shared the 1997 Nobel Prize in Physics for developing methods to cool and trap atoms using laser light (laser cooling). His technique allows atoms to be slowed to near absolute zero, enabling precise measurements and atomic clocks. He served as U.S. Secretary of Energy under President Obama.
timeline: Demonstrated laser cooling of atoms at Bell Labs

name: Roger Tsien
summary: Roger Tsien was a Chinese-American biochemist who shared the 2008 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing green fluorescent protein (GFP) into a tool for visualizing biological processes. He engineered multiple colored variants of GFP, creating a rainbow of fluorescent proteins that enable scientists to tag and track different molecules simultaneously in living cells.
timeline: Created mFruit series of fluorescent proteins

name: Charles Kao
summary: Charles Kao was a Chinese-born British-American physicist who is known as the 'Father of Fiber Optics.' He discovered in 1966 that glass fibers could transmit light signals over long distances if impurities were reduced, enabling modern fiber optic telecommunications. He shared the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physics for this breakthrough.
timeline: Earned PhD from University College London
Corning produced first practical optical fiber
Became vice-chancellor of Chinese University of Hong Kong

name: Yuan Tseh Lee
summary: Yuan Tseh Lee is a Taiwanese chemist who shared the 1986 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing crossed molecular beam techniques for studying chemical reaction dynamics. His method enabled scientists to observe individual molecular collisions and understand reaction mechanisms at the atomic level. He later served as president of Taiwan's Academia Sinica.
timeline: Developed crossed molecular beams with Dudley Herschbach

name: Kailash Satyarthi
summary: Though primarily known as an activist, Kailash Satyarthi is a trained electrical engineer who won the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize for his struggle against child labor. His engineering background informed his systematic approach to documenting and combating child labor in factories, mines, and farms. He founded Bachpan Bachao Andolan (Save the Childhood Movement).
timeline: Born in Vidisha, Madhya Pradesh, India
Led Global March Against Child Labour

name: Kim Dae-joong
summary: Kim Dae-joong is a Korean geotechnical engineer who contributed to the development of tunnel and underground construction technology in South Korea. His engineering innovations in shield tunneling and ground reinforcement were crucial for building Seoul's extensive subway system and other underground infrastructure projects.

name: Bak Jeong-sun
summary: Bak Jeong-sun is a Korean soil scientist who developed improved soil management techniques for Korean agriculture. Her research on soil fertility, crop rotation, and sustainable farming practices has helped Korean farmers maintain productivity while protecting soil health. She has been an advocate for sustainable agricultural practices.

name: Lee Soo-sung
summary: Lee Soo-sung is a Korean marine engineer who contributed to the development of offshore engineering technology at major Korean shipbuilders. His research on floating production storage and offloading (FPSO) vessels and offshore platforms helped Korea become a world leader in offshore engineering and construction.
timeline: Korean offshore industry reached global leadership

name: Im Kwon-taek
summary: Im Kwon-taek is Korea's most prolific and celebrated film director, with over 100 films spanning 60 years. While not a scientist, his films including Sopyonje and Chunhyang documented Korean traditional culture and technology, preserving cultural knowledge through cinema. He received numerous international film awards and is considered a national treasure.
timeline: Sopyonje became first Korean film to attract 1 million viewers
Won Best Director at Cannes for Chihwaseon

name: Suh Nam Pyo
summary: Suh Nam Pyo is a Korean-American mechanical engineer at MIT who developed axiomatic design theory, a systematic approach to engineering design. His framework for making design decisions based on functional requirements and design parameters has been adopted in manufacturing and systems engineering worldwide. He also served as president of KAIST.
timeline: Earned PhD from Carnegie Mellon University

name: Noh Tae-won
summary: Noh Tae-won is a Korean physicist at Seoul National University who has made significant contributions to oxide electronics and complex oxide thin films. His research on perovskite materials and their electronic properties has advanced understanding of strongly correlated electron systems and potential applications in next-generation electronics.

name: Ko Eun
summary: While Ko Un is Korea's most celebrated poet (perennially nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature until personal controversies), his work extensively documents Korean history, science, and natural world. His epic poem Maninbo catalogs thousands of real Korean people including scientists and inventors, serving as a poetic encyclopedia of Korean life.
timeline: Born in Gunsan, North Jeolla Province
Nominated for Nobel Prize in Literature

name: Kim Myung-hwan
summary: Kim Myung-hwan is a Korean organic chemist who has contributed to the development of organic electronic materials at Yonsei University. His research on organic semiconductors and light-emitting materials has advanced Korean OLED display technology and organic solar cell development.

name: Sohn Myung-se
summary: Sohn Myung-se is a Korean archaeologist who discovered Paleolithic hand axes at Jeongok-ri in 1978, overturning the belief that East Asia had no Acheulean hand axe culture. This discovery by an American soldier-turned-archaeologist fundamentally changed our understanding of prehistoric human migration and technology development in East Asia.
timeline: Discovered Paleolithic hand axes at Jeongok-ri, Korea
Published discovery, challenged Movius Line theory

name: Bae Yong-joon
summary: Although Bae Yong-joon is famous as a Korean actor, he founded KeyEast entertainment and invested in technology startups. His entrepreneurial activities in the Korean Wave (Hallyu) demonstrated how cultural technology exports could be systematically developed, inspiring Korea's approach to cultural technology as a scientific discipline.

name: Gang Pan-seok
summary: Gang Pan-seok was a Korean geographer and environmental scientist who documented the geographical and ecological changes of the Korean Peninsula. His research on Korean river systems, land use patterns, and environmental degradation provided baseline data for Korea's later environmental protection efforts.

name: Kwon Young-dae
summary: Kwon Young-dae is a Korean biomedical engineer who developed advanced medical imaging and diagnostic systems. His research on ultrasound imaging technology and medical device development has contributed to Korea's growing medical technology sector, producing devices exported worldwide.

name: Hwang In-beom
summary: Hwang In-beom is a Korean space scientist who contributed to the development of South Korea's satellite technology. His work on the KOMPSAT (Korea Multi-Purpose Satellite) series helped establish Korea's space observation capabilities and satellite manufacturing industry.
